reviewText:
They took one of the best things about the first game, the combat, and jacked it up big time and made it the main focus of this game. The first game you mainly did combat with lighter weapons like a pistol, pump shotgun, single shot hunting rifle, and flare gun. You also did a lot more walking around. Here, it's less walking around and almost purely combat. You get more enemies poured on you and you get a arsenal of guns right out of a action game, like assault rifles, nail gun, uzi, and whatever else. PC Gamer says it's not as good as the first game. PC Gamer also gave Duke Nukem Forever a score of 80/100 when everyone knows it should've been 80/1000 lol.
It's a really fun game with a great unique combat system. Where the first game was heavy on story, this just gets to what made that game so great and expands on it big time: the combat. And the story is cool too. Not as good as the story from the first game but still good. Game is a blast, 7.5/10.

reviewText: Alan Wake is one of my favorite games of all time.  I found myself fully engrossed in every bit of that game.  The story itself was the merry result of a fruitful marriage of Twin Peaks, X-Files and Lost with a bit of Stephen King threw in for good measure.  This game is much less story-driven and much more action-driven which I didn't care for.  It's also insanely short.  I beat the game in about 5 hours.  It feels like more of an expansion pack.  It isn't exactly a sequel, and it's not a prequel, just a weird little thing set in the same universe somehow.  Also because a time-loop is a story point, you end up playing all the areas about three times and I grew bored of it easily.

not much to say here... If you enjoyed the other, glorious, alan wake game, chances are that you're going to mildly enjoy this one as well. The story itself is somewhat connected to previous installment, but it gets pretty repetitive, even if the game can be completed in less than 4 hours. I won't spoil the game telling you the reasons for this, but if you're going to play it you'll see. New weapons are somewhat interesting, graphics are well done, as was the case the the first game, even though the locations are nowhere near as spectacular. All things considered, you should probably give it a try if it's on sale and you really loved the first game, otherwise you may want to reconsider buying it.

I listed in my review of Alan Wake some of the things that caused me to have to spend 16 months slowly plodding through it. I guess I wasn't the only one who felt that way because pretty much all the issues of the first game were fixed with American Nightmare.

I am happy to say that Alan can now run like the middle aged man that he is instead of his ailing grandmother. The card driving issues have been removed entirely, because they don't let you drive in this game. And the camera issues I struggled with were less cumbersome in fights.

Along with those happy notes, I have to say I think American Nightmare is a great length for an expansion. The story is engaging and interesting, and it develops three more characters in quick order who are all unique. Well... as unique as you can get with stereotypes. But I'm not going down that road.

Out of all the improvements one did shine above all the rest, and that was the decision to have new weapon unlocks correspond with the number of manuscript pages you collect. When I found the first unlock case, I immediately wanted to search the entire map for every last page. Well Done!

In the end I enjoyed this game much more than the original, and I would say pick this one up on the next steam sale by itself.

Where can I begin? I love this game. It's significantly more combat-oriented than it's predecessor which, in some ways, is nice although it shifts the genre of the game from horror to survival. However, the game remains charming in itself and tells a new story in it's new theme. Scratch is possibly one of the best and most likeable villains I have come across and I sorely want to see more of him and his manic, devil-may-care attitude about murder and ruining lives. The environments are fun and the upgrades well-placed; I never found the game particularly hard or particularly easy, but just comfortable enough to enjoy the short little novela of the story. It's a satisfying taste of our beloved story and hugely out of shape, byronic hero until Alan Wake 2 is made.

I have strongly mixed feelings about this game. It seems like a step down from Alan Wake's deep, psychological undertones, but at the same time I'd like to see more developers take a franchise and just have fun with it in the way that Remedy did with American Nightmare. Overall, Remedy Entertainment just wants to have fun with the Alan Wake universe. I would not be suprised if the game is declared non-canon before Alan Wake 2.

As a spinoff semi-sequel to the original, it is small and doesn't really connect to the original story or gameplay 'feel' in a satisfying way.

Judged as a standalone game, it's a decent but very short story-driven action game about a guy with a flashlight running around fighting zombies.

The combat is exactly the same as the first game, but there are a few more weapons to unlock and a few unique enemies.
This game is a lot more combat focused, because the atmosphere isn't as heavy as the original and the additional firepower gives the game the ability to send about 50 enemies at you in a continuous wave without you getting axed to death within the first few seconds.

This game has major issues with longevity. The game literally has you play the same story 3 times with minor variations until you reach a somewhat climactic ending. It seems like a 2-hour gameplay experience copy-pasted to become a 6-hour gameplay experience, with a few extra explory bits here and there. Even in its complete form, it still feels short.

The story is a bit of a mixed bag. It's well-written, but too short and feels awkward when done three times over.

There are some other good points though. The recurring characters have some of the best dialogue in the series so far. Alan is as genre-savvy as ever so his second clash with the forces of darkness is enjoyable to watch. Characters from the original game have fantastic cameos that are only there to keep the plot in cryogenic stasis until Alan Wake 2, but still impart how awesome these characters are.
But best of all, American Nightmare shows you one of my favorite video game antagonists ever: Mr. Scratch. He's a sarcastic, more psychotic doppelganger of Alan Wake that shows up on TVs throughout the game, mocking you.

If you're a fan of Alan Wake and you think the game would work with a little more action, then this game is probably for you. If you enjoyed the deeper, more psychological parts of Alan Wake rather than the combat, you'll probably see this as a generic spinoff that won't help you cope with the long wait for Alan Wake 2.

Overall, I had fun, and though I don't think it's as good as Alan Wake, it deserves to be enjoyed just because it doesn't feel obligated to stay in line with the original. If it were marketed as a full sequel, I would be really disappointed, but it's about as much as I would hope for as a side project.

reviewText: Good story, unsettling atmosphere, but no massive flashlight.

Quick review:
Should you play this game? - Yes.
Will you enjoy it as much as the original Alan Wake? - Probably not, but you'll still have fun.

-------------------------
What I enjoyed:
* Additional, powerful weapons made me feel like a one-man army.
* Excellent visual quality.
* Interesting storyline that ties into the original.
* Well-executed live-action components sequences.
* Mr. Scratch (!!!)

My critique:

I purchased both Alan Wake and the American Nightmare sequel in a bundle, so I was able to play the sequel soon after completing the original game.  Perhaps I should have given some time between the two games, because the transition between the two games was a bit jarring.  American Nightmare, despite the name, lacked much of the horror atmosphere that kept me addicted to the previous game.  It was the little things; like Alan making self-referential wise cracks about his supposedly very serious mission, the much easier enemies, and the dead-panned voice acting of the NPCs.  I did not get the impression that Alan was fighting for his life and that of his wife against an unrelenting horrific force of darkness, but rather this was just something he did that was mildly irritating.  As in: Eh

Pros:
+A nice little follow up to the original story. A funny concept, like one of those cheesy movies like you've seen so many times, but can't really remember any.
+A major improvement on original combat system. Now, it's just feels like it have more freedom. Movement have become easier, gunplay is more friendly, overall - feels better now.

Cons:

Overall ~ It's a nice spin-off. Althrough, it would not cut for full new continuation/conclusion of the series (well, not so much of the series here, but you get the idea). Pick it on sales.

I’m assuming that most people playing this game played the original so I’ll focus on comparison between the two titles.  The major difference between the two games is that AW:AN has a stronger focus on combat, with more weapons and more enemy varieties than in the original game.  I found that I enjoyed it more than the original, mainly because the variety of different enemies kept things from becoming as repetitive (as did a shorter run time).  The thing I liked was that a few of the new enemies weren’t just killed in the same way as every other enemy in the series so alternate strategies had to be used.  As this game focuses more on the action, the horror has mostly been taken out of the game since batteries/ammo are easily replenished.  The original AW had a more interesting story, but the story in this game has some neat ideas and a gimmick that keeps things fun and engaging.

Alan Wake's American Nightmare builds on the plot on that of Alan Wake.

The story involves Alan Wake's usual nightmares but this time, his 'evil-twin' a.k.a. Mr. Scratch is terrorising nearby towns and turning them into darkness, setting a trap that turns back the time over and over again. Alan Wake travels from place to place: a barren wasteland, to an observatory, and a drive-in theatre, in an attempt to restore light and stop the darkness so he can confront Mr. Scratch and defeat him.

Overall the game is an expansion on that of its predecessor, adding on a variety of weapons that are unlockable by collecting manuscripts, which encourages exploration of the entire map. Unfortunately, the experience is cut short due to the lack of missions available in this expansion.

Nonetheless, a decent game and one I would truly recommend if one has completed its predecessor.
P.S. Check out my other review for details on Alan Wake.

Well... It's worth the money in a sale for a quick play but honestly... This game has nothing on the original game.  Very quickly it stands out that the main game mechanic which made this series unique has been tampered with and spoiled... The mechanic I am talking about is light.  Light is the key to defeating the darkness, and no idea lightbulbs went off in the developers heads that made this.

The First game had little weapons, and had multiple flashlight types, beyond your regular flashlight you could find a heavy duty flashlight and two lantern type lights that in a world of combating darkness was amazing... this game replaces atmosphere and light combat with dumbed down boring gun fighting, many weapons are now available such as an Uzi and M16 and to be blunt... they just dont fit.  The normal light from the flashlight no longer burns away dark... it simply does nothing, you must focus the flashlight to make it do anything... mostly it's just a case of focus light, spray uzi or M16 and repeat now this... is the ultimate sin... They basicly ruined the main combat mechanic that made this game special and replaced it with bland generic shooting.

There are only three areas in this game, and those get reused several times as a time loop plot device... the ever repeating events become dull and the newer enemys just don't make it interesting enough to make it enjoyable...  infact the other characters remembering the previous loops ahve having previous tasks already finished only highlights the boredom the developers must have realised would happen playing the same content over and over again.

The first game was dark... VERY dark and the dark fog and shimmering enemys gave me goose bumps... this game did nothing to make me feel dark was dangerous or intimidating, there was no eerie fog everywhere and no sense of dread that made you wish for teh next brightly lit area to come soon... the game just wasn't creapy, spooky, or scary... it just didn't do a good job at all.

The sandbox arcade mode where you fight till dawn is a fun addition, and it is fun to try and beat your friends scores and try to survive for the full 10 minutes untill dawn... actually that is almost the only time this game seems to remember that light is your ally...

So as I mentioned...   The game is worth a play as a sale price... it's just nowhere near as good as the first game.

It's an ok sequil to the original, but it just feels different. It's much shorter, has very little horror elements, and is much more combat oriented. Many of the core elements of the original (the manuscript pages and other collectables, shining the light on enemies to weaken them, etc.) have been dumbed down considerably. There are a couple of new enemies that I found really interesting (the Splitter and the Birdman) and an interesting twist on gameplay. The live-action cut-scenes were pretty cool, as well. It's kind of got a Mario 3 motif to it and it doesn't bring the story to any more of a closure than the original did. If it's cheap, pick it up, but I wouldn't really recommend full price for it.
Enjoyed this game.  It got a little bit repetitive near the end but ended just before becoming tedious.  The narrator tries a bit too hard to emulate Rod Serling...

Alan Wake's American Nightmare has pros and cons over the original game. The graphics are much better, and the mob AI is also improved substantially. The combat has improved 100%, it's actually FUN this time around. The entire weapon system has been redone, allowing you to unlock machene guns, much better flashlights, etc. However, it seems like this add-on to the original took what little story it had, and stretched it so far that it became very bland. No plot twists or any thought provoking mystery. Overall, I enjoyed the game. It only gives you about 6 hours of gameplay, but it's also only $15.\n\nPeople should note that this is not Alan Wake 2 (source: Remedy), and I think this is just a taist of improvements that have been made, although I really hope they get a new idea for the story. Prehaps something seemingly not attached to the previos games. If I see 'Alan Wake 2: The Rise of Mr. Scratch' or 'The Darkness Returns', I think I'm going to throw a fit.

Alan Wake's American Nightmare  was an improvement in every area over Alan Wake.  While Alan Wake was tedious and clumsy in movement, American Nightmare  was fluid and fast moving.  American Nightmare took away the lack of ammo element of the game and replaced it with more, faster enemies; a move that made gameplay fun and exhilirating.  The story in American Nightmare was well done with better paced voice acting all around.  In contrast, the original Alan Wake's voice segments were long and tedious.  Manuscript pages were now fun and relevant to find due to a game mechanic that tred the pages to next tier weaponry.  In Alan Wake, I found hunting the pages to be little reward for an often tedious treasure hunt (tedious due to the sloggy feel of Alan Wake in the first game).\n\nI fully recommend the American Nightmare, although a short story style game (less hours), its much more enjoyable in every way than the tedious (unrecommended) Alan Wake.

A very different take on Alan Wake, game play plays way bigger role here, and there are certain changes. For example: Alan Wake can run way longer than in the original game, in the original game he could run for like 5 bloody seconds. Here he can actually run. Atmosphere is different, but it's actually not bad atmosphere, it suits the whole game and the place where the game takes place in. And shooting is more fun than in the original game, but the thing that really makes this game for me is Mr.Scratch, who I would say might be best villain ever. He's hillariously creepy. He's psychotic killer and he enjoys every moment of it. Game is 6-7 hours long, which is again, not bad. Beacuse the game is cheaper than most games and most games go for bigger price for the same lenght. There is arcade mode, which is very addicting for me and there is so replay value for me. Beating highscores is pretty fun. Story line is still there, and it is good story line. I would give it like: 8-9/10

Alan Wake's American Nightmare... first of all, this is NOT a sequel, it is a spin-off.

Next to mention, AW:AN does have improved combat, movement, albeit a shorter game and more linear.

I am a disappointed on the story though. If you crave for some TIME LOOP setting, then your in for a treat. If you hate time loop, you'll dislike this game as you go back in time on the same three levels.

The atmosphere is still there, giving you a good idea of the messed up mind of Alan... and combatting the Taken again.

I briefly tried that Arcade Mode where you survive wave after wave of Taken. It is okay but not my thing on the long run.

So I would recommend this game if you loved AW and/or looking into something different for a change. You don't really need to have played AW in order to understand  American Nightmare but you do get a better idea of the surroundings, characters if you did.

My rating: 7.5 / 10

reviewText:
If you loved the main Alan Wake game, you'll probably like this one as well. Perhaps even love it, despite some of the more tedious turns, and the sometimes frustrating, monotonous combat sequences. If you only liked the original, but wasn't a big fan of it, chances are this game is not for you.

I played through the original AW twice. That game had a few shortcomings as well, but I liked its Lynchian setting and mood a lot. This game here, though, while not bad, is not really my cup of tea. It was worth playing through once, sure -- especially to keep up to date with the franchise --, but once was enough.

So, if you're a real fan, play this. If not, read some more reviews, perhaps check out a playthrough video or two before deciding on buying it.

I hope AW2, if Remedy ever makes that sequel, will be more (way more) like AW1 than this little detour. :)

I absolutely adore the Alan Wake series, but this one really let me down. Its narrative is related to the rest of the series, contrary to my initial reaction, and it drops some interesting tidbits about what's happening outside Alan Wake's insane dreamworld, but much of the dialogue and voice acting is pathetic (with the exception of the guy voicing Mr. Scratch and Alan). I did not like the shift in tone at first, but eventually it was justified by the narrative. That said, I really hope they return to the darker, horror-based tone of the rest of the series for the next true installment (which I fear might not come for a while). The graphics rival those of the previous entries, but the cinematics are cheesy live action video clips that are at times cringeworthy. Fans of the series who are craving to find out what the hell happened in that huge cliffhanger at the end of the first one and its subsequent DLC should definitely give this a try, just to hear the juicy hints about what actually happened. That said, Remedy needs to finally bring this story back into the real world and answer some questions, rather than keep producing hints about what is actually happening in this story. Otherwise I fear that one of my favorite tales in gaming might just fly off the rails.
Boringgggg don't buy this crappy game.

This is a fun follow-up to the original Alan Wake. The combat is actually more fun in this one and each combat sequence seems to actually have a sense of purpose. The game itself felt fairly short but the story did pick up where the first game left off and I was pleased with the way it all turned out. Although you can technically play this game without having experiencing the story of the first, I recommend you don't because there are quite a few spoilers since the story takes place about two years after the original. Still, if you just want a fairly quick single-player experience to run through, this game shouldn't take more than a day to complete. I certainly felt a sense of satisfaction when I beat it!

Compelling plot, great graphics and sound design, loaded with atmosphere, and decent gameplay add up to make this a very good experience. After playing Alan Wake I didn't expect anything else! The game mechanics that made Alan Wake feel fresh and innovative (fighting with light etc.) make a welcome return, but new to the frachise is an interesting story that plays around with temporality in a way usually reserved for the movies. Indeed, the whole experience feels (quite deliberately, I expect) cinematic.\n\nThis stand-alone expansion pack doesn't quite achieve the scope of its predecessor, Alan Wake, so I would recommend trying that game out first. Nevertheless, this stands as an enjoyable experience in its own right.

Ok, it cant match the original game - it's a DLC. The not-sequel to Alan Wake, the story takes place in the fictional TV show that showed up sometimes in the original Alan Wake, Night Springs. You, the Champion of Light have to defeat your evil double, the Herald of Darkness by doing various tasks to rewrite reality and kill said evil double, who plans on taking your place in the world and ruining everything.

The combat is improved from the original. The enemies have less light health than before and your flashlight only depletes light health when you are amplifying the light like in the original. You have access to more powerful weapons sooner, and can get even better weapons collecting the manuscript pages and using them to unlock weapon cases. The game gives out ammo like candy at least on normal difficulty, so there isn't much stress about bullet levels.

It appears to run on the same base engine that Alan Wake ran on, so the graphical quality and style mostly remains the same. The voice acting never really gets cringeworthy, and the music fits the right moments.

It's pretty good overall. The combat is better, the story is different and NOT a continuation of Alan Wake, you will go through three main areas in the game. It runs pretty short at around 3 hours. It feels more like a standalone DLC to Alan Wake rather than it's own game, and for 15 dollars I feel it is worth it. It is entertaining throughout the whole time, though the ending might leave some wanting more.

If you liked Alan Wake you will probably like this, and it probably won't sell too many people who didn't like it. For 15 dollars (or cheaper through sales) it is worth it.

For those of you who played and enjoyed the first Alan Wake game, come into this one with an open mind. As far as tone goes, this game couldn't be more different, replacing the elements of a mysterious thiller with the atmosphere of a pulp supernatural action flick.

This isn't really a bad thing, though. While less of a sequel than a low-budget side-story, the series still enjoys playing with the pacing of a level, giving you brief periods of exploration before attacking you at your more vulnerable moments. This is damged somewhat by the re-use of levels in the game, but the justification for this and the different approaches taken each time you revisit an area is very well done.

Where this game shines the most, however, is the story. Alan is trapped in Night Springs, the Twiligh Zone-esque show he created early in his career. While the previous predecesor explained his ability to change reality through writing only gave him the briefest glimmers of hope, this rendition allows gamers to experience a writer's power trip, one that allows Alan to quite literally rock the heavens after some careful planning and skill.

A special mention must also be given to the game's villian, Mr. Scratch. While the idea of an evil twin is a bit of a cliche, Mr. Scratch's showboating in everything he does is consistently entertaining. Few times  has a villian been so intriguing just through sheer personality and charisma.

Where can I begin? I love this game. It's significantly more combat-oriented than it's predecessor which, in some ways, is nice although it shifts the genre of the game from horror to survival. However, the game remains charming in itself and tells a new story in it's new theme. Scratch is possibly one of the best and most likeable villains I have come across and I sorely want to see more of him and his manic, devil-may-care attitude about murder and ruining lives. The environments are fun and the upgrades well-placed; I never found the game particularly hard or particularly easy, but just comfortable enough to enjoy the short little novela of the story. It's a satisfying taste of our beloved story and hugely out of shape, byronic hero until Alan Wake 2 is made.

so if you've played the first alan wake you'll know the story, if not you're not going to get quite a lot that goes on and why everythin's going on. this one unlike the first isn't a survival horror. it's more arcady action, it has a lot more fighting, and a lot smaller game world. if you're looking for more of the same, this isn't it, though it's a pretty decent game in it's own respect. here are some good points and some things that can be improved so you can decide for yourself

good pointsthe unique way of fighting like the first alan wake is still in here. no spoilers, i'm just gonna say that no other game that i know of does something like this and it works
the action. it's not surivival horror, it's a different genre (more actiony), but i still works
because of the action genre and the unique way of fighting, and because it's so short, it's quite replayable
the over the shoulder camera. it works out much better than a straight behind you camera
the story and dialogue are both good (the story provided you've played the first alan wake)
ammo boxes. it would be a bad things if it were a survival horror to have a case that replenishes all your ammo, but this is action so it's fine
some things that could be improved or implementedthe game world is small. i know it's impossibe to change now though and it's still fun, but the game world is quite small with
i finished the game in about 4 hours on normal, then played though again about half way on nightmare in about 2 or 3 hours. it's quite short
you need to find a certain amount of manuscript pages to get certain guns so it feels quite arcady and it sometimes feels like this one is more suited to a console that pc, but even if it was on console, i'd still play it
the verdictit's a good game. don't expect another survival horror at all, this is action. the story is good but if you haven't played the first alan wake yet, i'd recommend giving that a go first. american wasteland is a lot shorter and the game world is much smaller. this isn't an adventure in the way that you constantly go to new places, it's open world gameplay in set locations which aren't terribly big .not tiny, just not big by a long shot, but it gives you enough space to run around in fights. there aren't towns or npcs wandering around, just your objective locations and there might be an npc in that location. it's a good action game, and i recommend it to someone who's looking for a quick play (i finished the game in +-5 or 6 hours)

I recommend this game. Here's why.

1. It was a good sequel to Alan Wake.
2. It succeeded in making me care about the side characters.
3. It looks and sounds great.
4. It has a high score component the first game lacked and it was done well enough that I actually wish the first one had it too.
5. The achievements were challenging but not improbable. (This is my first Perfect Game).
6. (Potential Spoiler) The ending is a whole lot more satisfying than in AW.

With that said, here's a few things to keep in mind.

Alan Wake's American Nightmare is considerably shorter than the original. Assuming you've got some skill, you can Perfect this game in less than 20 hours. The original would take about 35-40. Because of the plot mechanics, you might feel like you're retreading content, which makes a somewhat short game, feel small. Lastly, this game lacks a lot of the pop reference that made the original so fun. The only thing that remains are the radio broadcasts and the TV Show.

If you already own Alan Wake, and feel like you need more, this game is a must. If you don't, you should stop reading this, and buy both of them.
Nice little pick-up for those who enjoyed the first Alan Wake.\n\nWould advise new players to get familiar with the original, otherwise the story might be a wee bit confusing.

Doesn't live up to its predecessor, but worthwhile nonetheless. If you didn't like the repetitive combat of Alan Wake, chances are you won't grow too fond of this though, seeing as the game doesn't add anything to the story and the focus was clearly shifted to combat.

this sequel to alan wake is more action oriented than the first one who was story oriented but do that make it a bad game ? no it is still really enjoyable and close the story of alan in an unspected way !

For those of you who played and enjoyed the first Alan Wake game, come into this one with an open mind. As far as tone goes, this game couldn't be more different, replacing the elements of a mysterious thiller with the atmosphere of a pulp supernatural action flick.

This isn't really a bad thing, though. While less of a sequel than a low-budget side-story, the series still enjoys playing with the pacing of a level, giving you brief periods of exploration before attacking you at your more vulnerable moments. This is damged somewhat by the re-use of levels in the game, but the justification for this and the different approaches taken each time you revisit an area is very well done.

Where this game shines the most, however, is the story. Alan is trapped in Night Springs, the Twiligh Zone-esque show he created early in his career. While the previous predecesor explained his ability to change reality through writing only gave him the briefest glimmers of hope, this rendition allows gamers to experience a writer's power trip, one that allows Alan to quite literally rock the heavens after some careful planning and skill.

A special mention must also be given to the game's villian, Mr. Scratch. While the idea of an evil twin is a bit of a cliche, Mr. Scratch's showboating in everything he does is consistently entertaining. Few times  has a villian been so intriguing just through sheer personality and charisma.

Pros, Cons and Recommendation

Pro
- Good continuation of the original story.
- Improved gunplay mechanics.
- New enemies with unique variation.
- Fun arcade mode.

Con
- Short main story (expected for arcade release).
- Story mode is essentially the 3 main chapters played over 3 times with increasing difficulty.
- Relatively easy.
- Anticlimactic ending.


Recommendation
Alan Wake American Nightmare is a good spinoff/continuation of the original story. The manuscripts, radio shows and TV spots add back story and new content. The gameplay is pretty solid with a more arcade style of fighting, which makes for a much easier game. The game is worth buying if you are interested in a continuation of the story, if you enjoy arcade shooters with leaderboards and you're not looking for a long storymode, I completed it in less than 5 hours.

Alan Wake's American Nightmare is very similar to the original game. It takes place inside a television show which is featured heavily in the original game. The storyline is a lot less complicated. This is a bit more of an arcade version.

The graphics are the same standard as the original version and looks good even on its lowest setting. They have added more blending of live action video and generated graphics. The blending works well and helps to tell the story effectively.

The sound track to this game is excellence during both game play and the cut scenes. The sound effects are good quality and effective in the game play.

The combat has been improved with more responsive controls which was a problem with the original game. There are more powerful weapons available in the game to dispatch your enemies with and yes, you will encounter a horde of new enemies as well.

It is an improvement from the original game and highly recommend it. However you will need to play the original game first so you will understand what hell this is all about.

If you wish to read my review of the original game please click HERE.

I would recommend to anyone who liked Alan Wake; the original needs to be played first though (including the special chapters) to appreciate this IMHO. Without wanting to spoil too much, this expands on the 'Mr. Scratch' stroyline. The story places Alan in an episode of 'Night Springs' (Twighlight Zone Parody), complete with bad voiceover guy and in general has a quite different 'feel' to the original being set in Arizona not spooky woodland. Gameplay has been expanded to include new enemies and weapons and it could be argued that this is simplay an expansion to set Alan in a more combat heavy role - as such the tension has been wound back, but I liked the feel of it. The arcade mode puts you in a basic wave survival scenario - again pushing the additional weapons and enemies.

The campaign seemed a bit short and after a while I felt like I was doing chores instead of progressing the story, but overall it was solid DLC. The overhaul of the flashlight system isn't really good or bad, but the classic campaign weapons got a serious reworking and they added a ton of new ones to boot.  They also added a lot more ammo—too much actually. Sure I ran out of ammo a few times but that was because I never bothered to run away or conserve—there was no need to. I could just stand around blasting Taken until my heart’s content and then go to the restock station. It really took away from the feel of the original game; not needing to ever really worry if you have enough to make it to the next checkpoint. Arcade mode is actually quite fun and a great option if you want to play something but don’t really want to get too involved. If you want to use any of the new weapons in Arcade mode, you need to play though the campaign as you now collect manuscript pages to unlock the new weapons.

reviewText:
Although this is standalone DLC, there really wouldn't be much point playing it without playing the main game as you'd be missing a whole lot of story. American Nightmare still has a similar method of storytelling as the main game, and now features a truly psychotic villain. Now assuming you've played Alan Wake, here's what's new in American Nightmare. There are several new enemies with unique abilities. Several new weapons. A slightly modified HUD which has a more modern look to it. There is only 1 type of flashlight. Batteries fully recharge in about 2 seconds. Ammo is no longer scarce, with ammo boxes that completely resupply you with ammo and batteries. These boxes also replenish after a couple of minutes. Since you have more ammo, you will also be fighting more enemies at any given time. The overall game has a more action-arcade feel to it. There is even an arcade mode where you fight waves of enemies and then get a score with leaderboards support.

Bottom Line: If you liked Alan Wake, you need to get this game.

This is a fun follow-up to the original Alan Wake. The combat is actually more fun in this one and each combat sequence seems to actually have a sense of purpose. The game itself felt fairly short but the story did pick up where the first game left off and I was pleased with the way it all turned out. Although you can technically play this game without having experiencing the story of the first, I recommend you don't because there are quite a few spoilers since the story takes place about two years after the original. Still, if you just want a fairly quick single-player experience to run through, this game shouldn't take more than a day to complete. I certainly felt a sense of satisfaction when I beat it!
Short, but fun!

Pros, Cons and Recommendation

Pro
- Good continuation of the original story.
- Improved gunplay mechanics.
- New enemies with unique variation.
- Fun arcade mode.

Con
- Short main story (expected for arcade release).
- Story mode is essentially the 3 main chapters played over 3 times with increasing difficulty.
- Relatively easy.
- Anticlimactic ending.


Recommendation
Alan Wake American Nightmare is a good spinoff/continuation of the original story. The manuscripts, radio shows and TV spots add back story and new content. The gameplay is pretty solid with a more arcade style of fighting, which makes for a much easier game. The game is worth buying if you are interested in a continuation of the story, if you enjoy arcade shooters with leaderboards and you're not looking for a long storymode, I completed it in less than 5 hours.

Score
6/10 - I give the game a 6/10 based on the facts that I am more interested in the storymode vs arcade gameplay. I feel good knowing I got the game for less than $10.

Mr Scratch, best villain I've seen in a while?

The nature of the gameplay and story make this a bit more repetitive than the main game but a charismatic and devious villain makes this extension of alan wake worth playing through.

Thematically this gave me a The Dark Half" and "Army of Darkness" vibe the whole way through.

reviewText: Its a good game i like the combat but it does begin to be very repetative towards the end of the game

It's hard to recommend this title. In a way it started out as a nice, albeit quite cheesy, video game based off of the original. The narrative, one of the best things of the previous title, is extremely silly. A complete joke compared to the original. The game has you explore a handful of regions three times in a row, explained in the story as some kind of time cycle or trial-and-error run as Alan Wake tries to re-write his story. As far as gameplay is concerned, it means you'll spend doing roughly the same stuff over and over again and simply feels lazy on the part of the developers. The areas are okay, certainly not as atmospheric as the Pacific North West of the original. The game is considerably short as well, clocking in at three hours at most (I've finished my run in 2.5 hours). As short as it is, the game actually starts to drag halfway through since there isn't any new in terms of scenery. Gameplay-wise, however, it is as solid as the previous title. The enemies are diverse and the gunplay, mixed with the light mechanic, still feels as fresh as in the original. Ammunition is less scarce so the survival aspect that was present in the original is gone (safe havens are also more frequent), though this isn't all too bad. As a standalone it is hard to recommend, though I guess it should be seen as more of an expansion or perhaps (standalone) DLC. Taking the price-tag into account, I'm giving the game the benefit of the doubt. I feel the gameplay is enough to carry it.\n\nBottom line is that it is a fun game to kill an evening, but don't expect this to be Alan Wake 2"."

Alan Wake’s American Nightmare is a third person shooter in the psychological horror genre.  It is a stand-alone DLC that continues the story of the original Alan Wake game.

You play as Alan again fighting against his evil alter-ego and his minions of darkness.  He still wields up to six weapons – 1-hand gun, 2-hand gun, flare gun, flares, flashbang grenades and, most crucial, a flashlight.  The flashlight is required to remove the enemy shields in order to make them vulnerable to your guns.  Ammo (and batteries for your flashlight) are everywhere and there are quite a few more guns to choose from.

The story this time around pits you against your doppelganger, created by the Dark Presence.  There are some new interesting variations on the minions you face which helps against monotony.   What doesn’t help is that the three zones that the story takes you through get re-used three times each, creating nine areas to complete the game.  They do their creative best to make things a little different each time through, but there is no way to hide the inevitable repetition.

The graphics have been slightly updated from the original.  There are some great cutscenes and the voice acting is still superb.  The real life actor playing Alan Wake has some choice scenes playing the evil twin and taunting Alan through videos you can play on various TV sets.

They have toned down the many collectibles from the first game.  There are 50+ manuscript pages to find and these provide story exposition and are required to unlock better weapons.  Likewise, there are only 12 achievements now and half are associated with the new Arcade Mode.  Arcade Mode removes the storyline completely and allows the player to try and survive the night in different maps against waves of enemies.  You can compare your scores against your friends….still no co-op or multi-player available.

American Nightmare’s Story Mode can easily be completed in less than five hours, although the Arcade Mode can provide some additional hours of fun.  Overall, worth playing if you wait for the right Steam sale.

reviewText:
An interesting follow-up to Alan Wake. Is it a sequel? No, not really. Is it a DLC? No, it is stand-alone. I guess then we can call it an expansion pack.

The story is pretty short compared to the first Alan Wake, but it is kept interesting by fast pacing and a great progression of story elements.

This time, the story is narrated as if it were an episode of Night Springs (Twilight Zone). I absolutely adore this homage, and palying through and hearing the narration in this way really made me enjoy it more.

The videos you see on the random TVs are mainly Mr. Scratch addressing Alan directly. We get to see how twisted he is, and how he delights in what he does. I think this was a great addition to the game's story elements.

Shooting, the flashlight, the HUD, and a bunch of other mechanics have been streamlined to be faster. You're more agile and nimble, and combat is much more fast due to this. This takes some of the tension of the story mode, but it is still enjoyable.

There are tons of new weapons, with some great cameos by the m14, m4, and the AA-12, as well as the MAC-10.

I'm not interested in the Arcade mode, but I've played a round and I can see it being enjoyable and challenging.

All in all, an excellent expansion to Alan Wake that clarifies some things and mystifies some even further.

Totally worth it if you loved Alan Wake.

With the utmost relief, I can honestly say that Alan Wake's American Nightmare does the franchise justice. It certainly isn't one of the games where the end justifies the means".\n\nAmerican Nightmare takes place over three distinct levels. The longevity of the game lies within its plot: Alan Wake is put into a time loop by his sinister doppelganger
date: Mr. Scratch. Replaying the same three levels multiple times with minor variations can become slightly tedious.\n\nThe payoff at the end is tough to swallow. This subplot wraps itself up abruptly and no one knows if the new revelations are canon. Fortunately
recommended: the journey to this sorry conclusion is a fun one. Combat is unchanged
hoursPlayed: a handful of new enemies are introduced
voteText: and NPC's are more colorful. But most significant is the wider variety of weapons

We're supposed to give this a bad review because it's a failed triple A franchise, but honestly it's not really that different than any other triple A franchise out there. The fighting is fun, the mechanics are ok, but the game is never really creepy the way Resident Evil 4's opening was. It's not really a horror game, it's more of a supernatural shooter with some ok mechanics. What I think might make Alan Wake important is what it raises about triple A games and why some games become flagships like Halo or Uncharted and some end up like Alan Wake, because this is really not that different than any other blockbuster I've played recently. That said it's a horror game we're you're supposed to be afraid of what's out there, but then has a collection mechanic and more ammo drops than bad guys. They really should have just made the combat more in depth or maybe worked on disabling you a bit more and a little more oh ♥♥♥♥ run sequences. I never once even flinched leaving the safety of the light to find manuscrapt pages. These people need to play Amnesia more and Biohazard less.

reviewText: A very different take on Alan Wake, game play plays way bigger role here, and there are certain changes. For example: Alan Wake can run way longer than in the original game, in the original game he could run for like 5 bloody seconds. Here he can actually run. Atmosphere is different, but it's actually not bad atmosphere, it suits the whole game and the place where the game takes place in. And shooting is more fun than in the original game, but the thing that really makes this game for me is Mr.Scratch, who I would say might be best villain ever. He's hillariously creepy. He's psychotic killer and he enjoys every moment of it. Game is 6-7 hours long, which is again, not bad. Beacuse the game is cheaper than most games and most games go for bigger price for the same lenght. There is arcade mode, which is very addicting for me and there is so replay value for me. Beating highscores is pretty fun. Story line is still there, and it is good story line. I would give it like: 8-9/10
Good for the price.

A good game, but not a sequel to the events originally described in the former Alan Wake (which is a bit of a shame).

The plot is overall acceptable, but in the end some choices make the game less enjoyable than what it could be. Neverthless, the style is quite intriguing and while not being entirely unique you happen to walk through several beatiful settings (which sadly happen to repeat a lot, though).

Everything gameplay related and possibly voice actors related is literally ported from the earlier Alan Wake, with the benefits and drawback of a game that by now is a few years old. The engine still does its job but you'll happen to feel a need for something fresh, which is quite likely the point where the soundtrack excels (with some impressive - and fun - moments).

Overall it's a good game, but it could have been a much more interesting project if it wasn't going to be an Alan Wake spin off (you still feel like playing a game that was crumped a bit to fit either budget limits or time deadines).

Brilliant game! I paid just a bit under $10 for the Alan Wake bundle. At the time, the first Alan Wake was selling individually for $7.50 which means this game was pretty much under $3. But it is a full on game that continues the story of the first, or at least tries to explain more.

It was worth every friggen cent! I actually liked this better than the first game. But at the same time you need to play the first to understand what is happening story-wise and how the game engine mechanics have evolved.

A short bit of DLC that hit the spot.  This is not a long game, this is not an Alan Wake 2.  It is a small adventure to burn through in a long night.  The original Alan Wake game had some issues, combat and running could be a pain, some elements were left over from previous builds, somethings just didn't work right together.  American Nightmare delivers a tighter experience.  Combat is given a boost with new enemies and new weapons, and running away is now an option.  Ammo and weapons stay with you, while there's many ammo depots with infinite ammo around, this at least means when you find a weapon you like you're not going to lose it for the next scene or segment.  Driving is gone.  The darkness don't talk nearly as much, they still say a few things, but gone are the long winded reciting the rules of the park.\n\nThe story is not for everyone, be warned, it is groundhog day over three maps, and its style" is prevelant

reviewText:
Pros of Alan Wake's American Nightmare(got it and the original Alan Wake on steam during the 2013 steam holiday sale):

I absolutely adore the Alan Wake series, but this one really let me down. Its narrative is related to the rest of the series, contrary to my initial reaction, and it drops some interesting tidbits about what's happening outside Alan Wake's insane dreamworld, but much of the dialogue and voice acting is pathetic (with the exception of the guy voicing Mr. Scratch and Alan). I did not like the shift in tone at first, but eventually it was justified by the narrative. That said, I really hope they return to the darker, horror-based tone of the rest of the series for the next true installment (which I fear might not come for a while). The graphics rival those of the previous entries, but the cinematics are cheesy live action video clips that are at times cringeworthy. Fans of the series who are craving to find out what the hell happened in that huge cliffhanger at the end of the first one and its subsequent DLC should definitely give this a try, just to hear the juicy hints about what actually happened. That said, Remedy needs to finally bring this story back into the real world and answer some questions, rather than keep producing hints about what is actually happening in this story. Otherwise I fear that one of my favorite tales in gaming might just fly off the rails.

It certainly isn't one of the games where the end justifies the means".\n\nAmerican Nightmare takes place over three distinct levels. The Champion of Light is back and better than ever in this expansion. I would definitely recommend playing the original Alan Wake first, as it's a great game with an intriguing and engrossing story, but American Nightmare is just plain fun. It doesn't have quite the survival horror feel of the original; a hugely expanded arsenal of weapons makes defeating Taken a pleasure rather than a struggle. The option to turn off motion blur is the single greatest change between the two games, and it makes American Nightmare much more enjoyable. The story is still mysterious, and I was amazingly gratified at its beautiful conclusion, even though Alan's fate is still uncertain. The arcade mode is a nice addition and a great example of a survival mode that is difficult yet winnable.

reviewText: Even though the game has lost its thrilling moments and the story feels like filler in the grand scheme – making me not care much about Alan this time – Alan Wake’s American Nightmare is still a good and entertaining shooter. The story will last around four hours and the Arcade Mode will keep you coming back if you enjoy that type of gameplay. Thinking about it now, Arcade Mode is a great feature and shows that the combat in American Nightmare is enjoyable and works, even when it’s used for scoring based gameplay. I hope Remedy takes this idea and builds on it in the sequel, but while we are waiting for Alan Wake 2, you can take part in this direct-to-DVD addition to the Alan Wake franchise that fans will most likely want to do.

Continues the original Alan Wake, but only in story. This sequel to Alan Wake is odd.

It's short, for one thing. The story mode took me 6 hours. The story continues where Alan Wake left off, but doesn't do much to make the plot any clearer. The beginning is confusing, the middle you understand and then the ending is sudden with a lot of questions unanswered and literally no final boss fight.

Secondly, the gameplay you know and love from Alan Wake isn't here anymore. Where Alan Wake used to make you scavenge for ammo, always making you count your bullets and making you panic whenever combat starts; American Nightmare shoves ammo down your throat, combat is easy (especially if you've played the previous game) and the game plays less with the fear of darkness. So gameplay is definitely changed into more action-y, and although this is explained in game.

So is American Nightmare a bad game? No... but I definitely have the feeling this isn't a sequel, just a glorified DLC. Was it fun to play though? Yes. It was. Should you get this game if you haven't played Alan Wake? No. Should you get it if you have? Definitely... but don't expect another game of equal quality.

The Good: Little more light-hearted than AW, more guns, Arizona is a welcome change from Bright Falls.
The Bad: Why change a winning formula, repeats levels, story is still vague, sudden ending, ridiculously short.

reviewText: If you are looking for a short gaming experience but with the depth of a large title then I highly suggest giving American Nightmare a go! Alan Wake's American Nightmare is something of a sequel to the original Alan Wake. From what I understand it's the continuation of the story and was intended to be either released episodically or as a stop gap between the first and second game. Sadly there isn't any news on a second game coming so far, beyond the 'to be continued' that you get at the end credits.

Anyway, the game itself is pretty good. It hasn't lost any of the voice acting or nice little bits. The Alan Wake series is one of the few games that actually makes me want to collect the collectibles,, which in this cases are manuscript pages that can be read. Each page reveals more of the world so The player can understand the world more.
This title is a lot more combat orientated that the original with more varied enemies and tougher ones at that. Not to worry though your arsenal can be upgraded through weapons cases that are unlocked by finding the aforementioned collectibles. 3 gets you an smg, 10 a magnum and so on.

I'd recommend this game, it's actually worth it's asking price, though replayability is low. There is a arcade mode that can make the game last a bit longer. Be aware that you really do need to like plot heavy games to really enjoy this title.

Gameplay: Similar to the original Alan Wake, but made even more fun with the addition of several new weapons (Including a nail-gun).

Story: The story is decent, not as good as the original Alan Wake's, but it is a parody so this is not a major issue.

Graphics: The levels are very detailed, particle effects are great, shadows are very detailed, overall the game looks very good.

Sound: The music is particularly good and the sound helps to immerse you into the Twilight-Zone inspired game world.

Re-playability: There is an additional mode, in which you survive against waves of enemies.

Alan Wake’s American Nightmare is a third person shooter in the psychological horror genre.  It is a stand-alone DLC that continues the story of the original Alan Wake game.

You play as Alan again fighting against his evil alter-ego and his minions of darkness.  He still wields up to six weapons – 1-hand gun, 2-hand gun, flare gun, flares, flashbang grenades and, most crucial, a flashlight.  The flashlight is required to remove the enemy shields in order to make them vulnerable to your guns.  Ammo (and batteries for your flashlight) are everywhere and there are quite a few more guns to choose from.

The story this time around pits you against your doppelganger, created by the Dark Presence.  There are some new interesting variations on the minions you face which helps against monotony.   What doesn’t help is that the three zones that the story takes you through get re-used three times each, creating nine areas to complete the game.  They do their creative best to make things a little different each time through, but there is no way to hide the inevitable repetition.

The graphics have been slightly updated from the original.  There are some great cutscenes and the voice acting is still superb.  The real life actor playing Alan Wake has some choice scenes playing the evil twin and taunting Alan through videos you can play on various TV sets.

They have toned down the many collectibles from the first game.  There are 50+ manuscript pages to find and these provide story exposition and are required to unlock better weapons.  Likewise, there are only 12 achievements now and half are associated with the new Arcade Mode.  Arcade Mode removes the storyline completely and allows the player to try and survive the night in different maps against waves of enemies.  You can compare your scores against your friends….still no co-op or multi-player available.

American Nightmare’s Story Mode can easily be completed in less than five hours, although the Arcade Mode can provide some additional hours of fun.  Overall, worth playing if you wait for the right Steam sale.

Excellent Action Thriller title.  Puts great emphasis on using light to blind the dark.  Leaves you always at the edge of your seat as the darkness slowly and quietly creeps up on you.\n\n

A good game, but not a sequel to the events originally described in the former Alan Wake (which is a bit of a shame).

The plot is overall acceptable, but in the end some choices make the game less enjoyable than what it could be. Neverthless, the style is quite intriguing and while not being entirely unique you happen to walk through several beatiful settings (which sadly happen to repeat a lot, though).

Everything gameplay related and possibly voice actors related is literally ported from the earlier Alan Wake, with the benefits and drawback of a game that by now is a few years old. The engine still does its job but you'll happen to feel a need for something fresh, which is quite likely the point where the soundtrack excels (with some impressive - and fun - moments).

Overall it's a good game, but it could have been a much more interesting project if it wasn't going to be an Alan Wake spin off (you still feel like playing a game that was crumped a bit to fit either budget limits or time deadines).

American Nightmare is a stand alone expansion to Alan Wake from Remedy Entertainment. Originally an Xbox live title this has made its way over to the PC with a few tweaks.

Graphics are not powerhouse hungry but its not going to make you vomit in disgust at its admitadly bland pallet. As this game is set mostly in the desert with minimal indoor environmets this game is no stranger to the colour brown. The PC version does look better than its console sibling with AA options and a HD texture pack.

The gameplay is very similar to the main game with a familar over the shoulder third person camera with a reasonable FOV. Ok its a very console orientated FOV and this game does play better with a gamepad than a keyboard and mouse although you want cry and bang your head on the desk if you dont have a gamepad. So I would recommend plugging in a pad and scooting your chair back a tad for a more comforatable experience. The weapons have a nice feel to them, the traditional pistol, rifle and shotgun are back with interesting additions such as the nail gun. There is enough variety of weapons around and plenty of ammo to keep gameplay fresh.

The flashlight returns to burn off the Darkness" which acts as a shield to enemies making them imune to bullets. But like in the main game the enemies are vunerable to all forms of lights

Especially when the game costs less than a pint. New to American Nightmare is an arcade mode. This is basically a horde mode escape the zombies make it till dawn affair. It has a couple of achievements and map unlocks but single player means its not something you are going to come back to.

So should you buy it? Have you played Alan Wake? If not go pick that up. Its not expensive

Wide range of enemies as well with more new enemies that keep it interesting and challenging through the game. Voice acting is done well but when talking to characters they don't move or show really any emotion, which makes it hard to connect to them. They introduced a new unlockable feature witch introduces an ever wider range of guns. The arcade mode supplies more replayability and is good fun, but not entirely challenging but you can unlock new levels as you progress.\n\n8.5/10 Great storyline, fresh ideas and an arcade mode that will keep you interested. Sadly, being a stand-alone dlc, it is short, round 4 hrs

reviewText: Just bad. They took out the survival horror feeling from the original and replaced it with a way too overpowered set of weapons that make the game too easy even on harder difficulty settings. I didn't even die once the whole playthrough.\nIMO the story is very cool but the ending has the same problem as Alan Wake: it is way too obvious and uninspired :(

The original Alan Wake, whats to say an amazing story and good gamplay, overall good game. Now American Nightmare is a little different, diviating off the main story the game has you fighting the darkness and Mr. Scrath. Now many people are put off by the main story itself because of its diviation from the first game, but the story is still a great experiance, with well thought out events and interesting weapons. Now the story is a bit repetitious visiting the same three areas three times and doing the same things. One main seller for me is the arcade mode fighting wave after wave of the darkness untill dawn is a good mechanic, however one dissapointment is that it is not co-op. Now the manuscript pages actually have a use the more pages you collect you can get special wepons in the story and arcade. My opinion is this game matches my expectaitions after it was released and i recomend it to anyone who wants fun fast paced semi-horror shooters.

An adequate cap to the first game's unfinished ending.  While it's clear this entry was crafted on a budget, reusing a handful of small but densely packed environments, you'll still manage to eek out a few entertaining hours of play.  And if you enjoyed the plot of the original but felt you were left hanging, this wraps things up nicely.\n\nI will say though, any sense of dread or horror from the original is lost.  The game is still dark, and centers on the same mechanics of light and shadow, but that sense of suspense is strangely absent.

This is the sequel of Alan Wake. The game doesn't have that great storyline as the first one had, altough it still decent and interesting even being shorter.

The horror touch of the prequel is completely gone, it has become an adventure/arcade shooter. I ran out of ammo only once in the entire game. I didn't have to change batteries the entire game because the flashlight recharges 10 times faster than the prequel. Graphics still the same and the level design is ok.

Gladly they've done improvements on the UI, and added a great amount of new weapons and original enemies to the game. The gameplay is faster paced and more action driven than the previous game.
Good game but could be more loyal to the original game.

Gameplay: Similar to the original Alan Wake, but made even more fun with the addition of several new weapons (Including a nail-gun).

Story: The story is decent, not as good as the original Alan Wake's, but it is a parody so this is not a major issue.

Graphics: The levels are very detailed, particle effects are great, shadows are very detailed, overall the game looks very good.

Sound: The music is particularly good and the sound helps to immerse you into the Twilight-Zone inspired game world.

Re-playability: There is an additional mode, in which you survive against waves of enemies.

Дополнение к практически шедевральному оригиналу,вышедшее в 2012 году.
Основные элементы геймплея сохранились,но явно чувствуется разница с оригиналом,главной проблемой которого была боевая система.В дополнении боевая система изменилась в лучшую сторону,уничтожились все недостатки боевки оригинала.
Вот только это уже не хоррор,а элементарный шутер,при том,что для того,чтобы умиреть в этой игре,надо очень сильно постараться,ибо сложность врагов..практически нулевая,враги убиваются пачками,при том,можно использовать  против всех врагов пп,являющийся универсальным оружием.
Вставки с актерами смотрятся просто великолепно,однако сам сюжет как мне кажется...скомканный,атмосфера присутствует,но такие детали,как в оригинале,опущены,потому через час игры хочется уже побыстрей пройти,ибо трижды бегать по одним и тем же локациям..напрягает малость.
Как итог,разработчик превосходно исправили главный недостаток оригинала,с тем же успехом растеряв хоррор и всякие намеки на сложность...

I seriously don't know why I bothered. I liked the original game; but, this game was just tedious.

Where I think it fails:
- It brings next to nothing new from the original game so there's no mystery
- Game-play is way too repetitive and offers nothing we haven't already seen
- Theme/Environment/Mood is isolated, lonely, and lacks interactivity
- As you progress in the game, nothing changes,same predictable crap, etc.
- The hidden pages don't offer much; they say a whole lot of the same exact thing
- The game is neither action, nor is a horror/thriller; rather, it seems like a feeble attempt at a mystery/adventure without enough story to make it so
- The game feels confined (which is good for horror titles) but it's just a put-off in this case
- This game makes it apparent that Alan Wake is suffering from a form of severe bi-polar dementia or schizophrenia, representing parts of his segmented life through each character, periodically relating to story lines from his previous writings (mainly 'The Hero of Light)

reviewText: Having played Alan Wake on 360 and PC, I would definitly recommend Alan Wake: American Nightmare for anyone that has enjoyed the original game. More action packed, than scary, this is a game that moves at a nice clip. Expect it to take 3-4 hours, so this is short but sweet!

The universe of Alan Wake is amazing and the writing is excellent. The graphics, character interactions, animations, and combat are all vastly improved for this short sequel to Alan Wake. Pick it up, support a decent game... and perhaps we'll get Alan Wake 2 to temper the need for more great storytelling games.

Just prepare to backtrack.
I love it it's a great little game had loads of fun playing it. Not long but had that Alan Wake feel to it and does not dissappoint! Would recommend it!

As a little something from Alan's Wake universe, American Nightmare presents itself as more action oriented spinoff of original game with cheesy plot straight out of The Twilight Zone. Interesting use of music and game mechanics from the original mix well with games setting, plot and fairly average playtime. I would say this is example of the ideal game to play inbetween big 100+ hours RPG games.

Alan Wakes american nightmare is an interesting game. It has solid gunplay and action but the story is hard to follow and their is alot of replaying of sections which are annoying. It is ok for a downloadable title. But if you want to play alan wake just play the original it is way better. 5.5/10

- 앨런웨이크 본편의 이야기를 마무리짓는 최종편 !

[ 보너스게임 ] 인 아케이드 모드는 적은 볼륨의 아쉬움을 보여주지만,
이번작에선 어느 정도 보강을 한 것 같다. 무기의 수도 늘어나고 적들의 종류도
늘어났으며 손전등을 비춰야 하는 시간도 줄어들어서 본편처럼 세월아 네월아
손전등만 비춰야 하는 불상사는 잘 일어나지 않는다. 전투가 강화되다 보니
전투만을 목적으로 한 아케이드 모드 역시 할만하다. 단, 똑같은 맵을 세 번이나
반복해야 하는 구성은 플레이어에게 지루함을 전달할 뿐이다.
또한 본편에서의 한 편의 공포소설을 방불케 하는 분위기가
이번 작에선 많이 없어졌기 때문에,
본편의 그 점이 맘에 들었던 유저들에겐 단점으로 다가올 수 있다... ;;

( 그냥.. 앨런웨이크 DLC로 나왔다면 괜찮았을 게임 . )

This is the sequel of Alan Wake. The game doesn't have that great storyline as the first one had, altough it still decent and interesting even being shorter.

The horror touch of the prequel is completely gone, it has become an adventure/arcade shooter. I ran out of ammo only once in the entire game. I didn't have to change batteries the entire game because the flashlight recharges 10 times faster than the prequel. Graphics still the same and the level design is ok.

Gladly they've done improvements on the UI, and added a great amount of new weapons and original enemies to the game. The gameplay is faster paced and more action driven than the previous game.
Good game but could be more loyal to the original game.
7.5/10

It's a short (takes a little over 3 hours to finish story mode) spin-off in the Alan Wake universe, focussing on combat (and almost ditching proper storytelling altogether). Hard to recommend at its full price, but definitely enjoyable as it tweaks the combat mechanics. Makes you wonder though, if the true Alan Wake sequel will still be a horror game or just a third person action game like this, storywise.

Оригинальный Alan Wake минус интересный сюжет(хотя за мистером Скрэтчом интересно наблюдать), минус интересные диалоги, плюс больше экшена(сомнительное новвоведение)... но играть все еще интересно. 7,5/10
Oh man, I bought the DLC too?

If you enjoyed the original Alan Wake then you will like American Nightmare as it continues and extends on the story from the orignal game and turns the game more into an arcade shooter and removes the suspense and horror aspects.

Not as story driven as the first Alan Wake but in it's own way is really good. The combat is really fun and the story keeps you there for ~4 hours it last. The only bad thing is that you do the story more then once in order to continue the story.

Took me four hours to complete American Nightmare. Not sure if I'm going to play the arcade mode - tried one and completed it on normal mode, but really not that impressed about wave-survival-stuff of that particular genre.\nOver-all decent game, although fairly cheap in its construction in regards to level creation - you play the same level multiple times with minor changes.... but the story told is decent and if you take the time to read the notes and watch the television 'shows' it's definitely money well spent.\n7/10 I do recommend.
